{{Use DMY dates|date=February 2015}} {{Use British English|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Margaret Belsky<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- just the pagename, without the File:/Image: prefix or [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Margaret Constance Owen<!--only use if different from name--> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1919|06|20|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Wareham, Dorset]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1989|01|26|1919|06|20|df=y}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = British | education = Bournemouth School of Art, [[Royal College of Art]] | alma_mater = | known_for = Illustration and cartoons | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = [[Franta Belsky]] | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | module = | native_name = | native_name_lang = }} '''Margaret Constance Belsky''' ''[[née]]'' Owen, better known by her [[nom de plume]] '''Belsky''', (20 June 1919 – 26 January 1989), was a [[Great Britain|British]] [[cartoonist]] and illustrator.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Biography: Margaret Belsky|url=http://www.cartoons.ac.uk/artists/margaretbelsky/biography|publisher=The British Cartoon Archive|accessdate=4 February 2015}}</ref>
Belsky was born on 20 June 1919 in [[Wareham, Dorset]] to Albert Edward Owen and Margaret Constance Davies-Bunton.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bryant|first1=Mark|title=Belsky [née Owen], Margaret Constance (1919-1989), cartoonist and illustrator|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/57137|publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/57137|date=September 2004}}</ref> She attended the Bournemouth School of Art and later studied engraving and illustration at the [[Royal College of Art]]. Belsky won a cartoon competition for ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'' in the 1930s.<ref name=":0" /> It was at the Royal College of Art that she met her future husband, [[Czechoslovakia|Czech]] exile and sculptor, [[Franta Belsky]]. Franta introduced her work to editors he knew at the magazine ''[[Lilliput (magazine)|Lilliput]]'', where Belsky became a regular contributor.<ref name=obit>{{cite news|title=Margaret Belsky|url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/newspaperRetrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=DateAscend&tabID=T003&prodId=TTDA&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchId=R1&searchType=BasicSearchForm&currentPosition=2&qrySerId=Locale%28en%2C%2C%29%3AFQE%3D%28tx%2CNone%2C15%29Margaret+Belsky%24&retrieveFormat=MULTIPAGE_DOCUMENT&userGroupName=lancs&inPS=true&contentSet=LTO&&docId=&docLevel=FASCIMILE&workId=&relevancePageBatch=IF501758141&contentSet=TDA&callistoContentSet=TDA&docPage=article&hilite=y|accessdate=24 August 2016|work=The Times|date=2 February 1989}}</ref>
In 1944, Margaret and Franta married, with Belsky taking on her husband's name for her single word signature, disguising her gender.<ref name=obit /> Belsky started working for the ''[[Daily Herald (UK newspaper)|Daily Herald]]'' in 1951 and became their first ever [[pocket cartoon]]ist, at the same time becoming the first woman to draw a daily front-page cartoon.<ref name=":0" />
Belsky was dismissive of her own work, calling herself "just a hack." She didn't collect her work, though it was estimated that she may have drawn more than 6,000 cartoons while working for the ''Daily Herald''. When the ''Daily Herald'', later ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', was taken over by [[Rupert Murdoch]] in 1969, Belsky refused to work for him. Instead she contributed cartoons for many other newspapers and magazines, including ''[[The Strand Magazine]]'', ''Punch'', ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[John Bull (magazine)|John Bull]]'' and ''[[Sunday Graphic]]''. She also became an illustrator for children's books, including designing the covers for various Penguin books.<ref name=":0" /> Belsky died on 26 January 1989.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Public Sculpture of Greater Manchester|last = Wyke|first = Terry|publisher = Liverpool University Press|year = 2005|isbn = 9780853235675|location = |pages = 437–438}}</ref>
